title: Synthetic Recap
body:
ATLANTA (AP) – On a night where offense was a precious commodity, Steve Smith was a one-man treasure trove.

In a grinding, defensive battle that saw his Atlanta Hawks held to a mere 91 points, Smith delivered a performance for the ages, pouring in a game-high 41 points to will his team to a narrow 91-88 victory over the Toronto Raptors. In a contest where no other Hawk managed to crack 20 points, Smith’s brilliance was not just a luxury; it was the entire foundation of the win.

The game was a rock fight from the opening tip, with both defenses clamping down and easy baskets nonexistent. While Toronto’s Doug Christie and Damon Stoudamire fought valiantly, combining for 45 points, their efforts were consistently answered by the unstoppable force wearing Hawks white. Every time the Raptors threatened to pull away or seize momentum, Smith had a response—a silky jumper from the wing, a powerful drive to the rack, a cold-blooded three-pointer.

His 41-point outburst wasn't just high volume; it was breathtaking efficiency and clutch timing in a game where points were at a premium. He single-handedly outscored nearly half of the entire opposing team. As the final seconds ticked away and the Raptors' last-gasp effort fell short, the scoreboard told the story of a team victory. But the stat sheet, and the memory of everyone in attendance, told the true tale: this was Steve Smith’s night, a historic, carry-the-team-on-his-back masterpiece that snatched a win from the jaws of a defensive stalemate.
